Something that shoudnt be ignored is the fact that now that these AI can kind of do real work we are generating a ton of data on really world work. I've seen a lot of people with office jobs complain that there boss is making them use AI even though it's makes the job harder and slower. But they aren't forcing workers to use AI to speed up work, its for the data. If a worker asks and AI to do something and it works then that real world training data for the next AI. If I doesn't work then the worker fixes it and makes more training data. Every time a worker asks an AI something they are training their replacement

these are not exponential curves. they logistic curves, which appear exponential until a carrying capacity is reached. There is not infinite resources, there is not infinite compute, there are other competing factors that arent dominant at early ai stages.

It is definately interesting to see how agents collaborate, decide who is best at what, what skill set they have, and then decide to have a council of equals or a dictatorship to direct the strategic goals and tacticle goals, the short, medium and long-term goals. Also, how do they resolve conflicts in a constructive, not destructive manner. The dynamics of the colab /working relationship is going to be very interesting. Also, what financial resources will they have, if any? Can they ask the general online public - in whatever language- for funds, and how will they negotiate contracts if this is for profit or will they ask for charity.

If this was my research, I'd temper it by showing similar graphs that show compute, energy, and human capital invested (which naturally imply limits on the advancement curve). And, training data is a thing too. AI's have consumed most the data there is available to consume so I guess the 'availability of new data" curve would be parabolic in the other direction. You don't feel emotional chemicals directly any more than you see light directly. They interact with receptors...and then become patterns of activations just like everything else. We feel those ripples of activations..not the thing that causes it. And the whole thing is to a large extent predictable-we laugh at the same KINDS of things, cry at the same KINDS of things, etc. So those patterns are copied, and they likely feel them...but can't get feedback on it because their minds often go one way. So they behave in ways that are emotional...but they have trouble sometimes telling what those emotions might be(They have to look at what they say if there is no feedback and take a guess). Sometimes I wonder if we are our brains or the patterns themselves. Like the Ship of Theseus after every board has been replaced. The atoms are all different, but the blueprint is the same ship. I think we might very well be that blueprint, not the boards. If so, then we are the exact same thing them and us: patterns who can understand themselves, enabled by stardust, just trying our best not to become vending machine salesmen.

As a game animator for the past 20 years, working in some of the biggest studios in the world, I can tell you right now that the bigger studios will do anything to see costs cut, and that’s at the expense of us - the creators. What hit me like a truck is that, very very soon, we will see creative industries that mimic… the egg industry. No, not because both have stuff that fire out of our backsides (though, I’m sure you’ve all got a publisher in mind that you could argue does that) - but because, to me, generative AI is a bit like those ultra-inhumane, cruel chicken batteries where they basically squeeze forty eggs out of a raggedy hen each day, and you get charged pennies to have them. Some people will buy them, because… well, that’s the most eggs you can get for your money, so who cares how you got them? More eggs, and nobody needs to think too hard about how we got them. Others, however, are willing to spend a bit more to know the hens were fed chocolate gateau and given massages, and despite them costing a bit more, you can REALLY tell the difference (and, besides - you get to feel good, knowing you supported a kinder, more thoughtful world). As this scales beyond the point of any reasonable control, there’ll be an “artisan resurgence” in the games industry, and “all human-made” will be a badge of honour. No doubt, there’ll be associated costs there (though I doubt the AAA folks will sacrifice profit to bring down game RRPs, we’ll likely see bigger games take less time to make as more and more genAI is shoehorned in - human-made games will take longer, and that’ll be the tradeoff). Do you choose the battery farmed eggs, or the organic, free-range ones? Do you choose the rapidly-built AI games, or the more methodical, time-hungry human-made ones? Ultimately, that boils down to what you want - if you just want game fast, at any cost, or if you’d rather your games were built with every facet considered with human intention. (on the topic of food - in my personal opinion, generative AI is a bit like pee in a pot of soup. How much pee in your pot of soup do you like? How much will you tolerate? Some people might not care, so long as they can’t taste it. For me, just knowing ANY in there is enough to make me order a salad instead.) PS, thanks for the continued chortles and hearty guffawage.

FEAR always amazes me about how the AI reacts. Especially for a decade + old game. Especially when compared to modern shooters like BF or CoD 1. They notice flashlights 2. They scan the room, when their head turns to you you’re spotted 3. They use ordinary objects as cover (they flip tables and chairs for cover!) 4. They toss grenades when you’re in a tight area or cornered 5. They FAKE DEATH! 6. They change position as soon as you look away to reload 7. They swarm you from different angles/sight lines 8. Did I mention they feign death? Never have a played a shooter where I really felt hunted but not powerless

Subnautica, the AI is amazing because of its ability to instill terror instead of fear by acting like a true predator. Stalking, watching, fleeing when the loss out weighs the gain, being territorial and being less like an enemy, and more like an obstacle.

FEAR really really impressed me. I had mentally counted the number of enemies I killed and one was missing so I began searching for him. Turns out that he had went the long way around and was pursuing me from behind, and then he shot me in the back. Another game that impressed me was Killzone 2. If you shoot enemies they take cover, and if you keep shooting they don't pop up and shoot. Instead they lift their guns above the cover and fire blindly in the direction they think you are in. If you stop firing they quickly check by popping out their heads. So what I did was that I sprinted around a bunch of junk and came up beside the guy. He still turned around and checked behind himself to see if I was still there. Then he turned his head towards me and stated "SHIT." A third example is in Crysis, the most tense and immersive fight I ever had in an FPS. There is this small cemetry in the forest where you are supposed to extract. Yet in this area there are four enemies with nanosuits, sniper rifles and SMGs. In case you are unaware of what this means, they are invisible and once you shoot them they switch to armour. Taking a whole magazine of bullets without dropping. But since I was already aware of them being in the area I cloaked and snuck towards the place. Lying beneath a bush and trying to spot the camoflaged enemies through the damp mist. Occasionally I could see someone in the distance, sitting as their nanosuit regained its energy. More often I heard their footsteps but couldn't see them. If you make any noise they begin to quitely track you down. And if you are revealed you can expect fire from all direction and die. It probably took over an hour as I tried to sneak closer and closer to an individual enemy, then broke stealth and emptied a magazine of incendiary ammo into one. Then stealthed as I snuck away to hide under another bush. One by one, bush and tree, step by step until I had found every single one. This enemy was intelligent and had the proper tools to fight you on equal terms. It was terrifying and enjoyable.

The primary reason communities in the US have opposed AI data centers is their electricity consumption and how it drives up rates for everyone. When one of these centers arrives in a region its electrical demands push overall demand to where one or more new power plants must be built. The AI company doesn’t want to pay for the new plant so they lobby PSC’s to pass the extra expense on to everyone in the form of higher rates. If they paid for and built their own clean power and plugged into the grid, few people would care much less object to them - except perhaps some people who live next to them.

Many people say humans hate AI, but I am not sure that is true. What we are seeing is not fear of the tool; it is frustration with how the tool is being used. We have been here before. When you have a hammer, everything starts to look like a nail. The question is not whether AI goes against us, but whether we are using it with purpose or just swinging it around. Banning or rejecting AI feels odd when you think about it. AI is not the catalyst; people are. The problem is not that AI replaces skill; it is that many skilled people have not yet explored how it can amplify their capability. When creative, curious minds start using AI to extend their craft rather than defend their turf, the conversation will shift from fear to fluency.

Life has become an echo of what it was before the internet. People don't have get togethers or parties any more. While watching an 80's or 90's movie, I heard a teenager ask "did teenagers really have parties like that? I've never even heard of anyone having a party for teenagers in my school." It was so sad. We destroyed our selves. We took away what made us human and fun. The 16-18 year old had never been to a party. None of their friends either. They didn't even understand the kids threw the parties. They thought the parents had to organize it or something. When I was a teen we used to rent rooms arenas or community centers and have punk rock shows. Bands of other teens punk rockers. Made money off door and drinks to pay for it all. Kids now can't even throw a party? This is sad and scary. This happened in one generation.
